questions.question: A single taxpayer under age 65 is generally required to file a federal income tax return when gross income equals or exceeds:

options.A: The personal exemption amount
options.B: The standard deduction amount
options.C: The sum of the personal exemption and standard deduction

questions.explanation: For single taxpayers under 65, the filing threshold is generally equal to the standard deduction amount. Since personal exemptions were suspended by the TCJA (2018-2025), the filing threshold is now just the standard deduction. For 2024, this is $14,600 for single filers under 65.
questions.tip: Filing threshold = standard deduction (personal exemptions suspended through 2025).

questions.question: A taxpayer with self-employment income must file a return if net self-employment earnings are at least:

options.D: The standard deduction amount

questions.explanation: A taxpayer must file a federal income tax return if net self-employment income is $400 or more, regardless of other income or the filing threshold. This lower threshold ensures self-employment tax is paid on all qualifying self-employment income.
questions.tip: Self-employment = $400 threshold, much lower than standard filing threshold.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a consequence of filing married filing separately?

options.A: Loss of earned income credit eligibility
options.B: Loss of child tax credit eligibility
options.C: Reduced IRA contribution limits
options.D: Lower phase-out thresholds for some deductions

questions.explanation: IRA contribution limits are the same regardless of filing status (though deduction limits may differ). However, married filing separately results in loss of earned income credit, reduced eligibility for child tax credit, lower phase-out thresholds, and inability to deduct student loan interest.
questions.tip: MFS loses many credits and deductions but IRA contribution limits stay the same.

questions.question: For calendar-year individual taxpayers, the original due date for Form 1040 is:

options.A: March 15
options.B: April 15
options.C: April 30
options.D: June 15

questions.explanation: Individual income tax returns (Form 1040) for calendar-year taxpayers are due April 15 following the close of the tax year. If April 15 falls on a weekend or holiday, the due date is the next business day. An automatic 6-month extension to October 15 is available.
questions.tip: Individual returns = April 15. Extension gives 6 months to October 15.

questions.question: Filing Form 4868 for an automatic extension:

options.A: Extends both the time to file and time to pay
options.B: Extends only the time to file, not the time to pay
options.C: Requires approval from the IRS
options.D: Is only available to taxpayers expecting a refund

questions.explanation: Form 4868 provides an automatic 6-month extension of time to FILE (no approval needed), but it does NOT extend the time to PAY. Taxes owed are still due by April 15, and interest and penalties accrue on any unpaid balance from that date.
questions.tip: Extension to file â‰  extension to pay. Always pay by April 15 to avoid penalties and interest.

questions.question: Estimated tax payments for individuals are due on all of the following dates EXCEPT:

options.A: April 15
options.B: June 15
options.C: August 15
options.D: January 15

questions.explanation: Estimated tax payments are due April 15, June 15, September 15, and January 15 of the following year. Note the uneven spacing - the third quarter payment is September 15, not August 15. This gives taxpayers extra time for the summer period.
questions.tip: Estimated tax dates: 4/15, 6/15, 9/15, 1/15. Notice Q3 is September, not August.

questions.question: A taxpayer with prior year AGI of $180,000 can avoid the underpayment penalty for estimated taxes by paying at least what percentage of the prior year's tax liability through withholding and estimated payments?
questions.explanation: Taxpayers can avoid the estimated tax underpayment penalty by paying the lesser of 90% of current year tax or 100% of prior year tax (110% if prior year AGI exceeded $150,000, or $75,000 if MFS). With AGI of $180,000, the higher 110% threshold applies.
questions.tip: Prior year AGI > $150K = must pay 110% of prior year tax (not 100%) for safe harbor.

questions.question: Under current rules, Form W-4 completed by employees for withholding purposes:

options.A: Requires the employee to specify a number of allowances
options.B: Uses a system based on withholding allowances
options.C: Is based on factors like filing status, multiple jobs, and deductions
options.D: Must be submitted annually by all employees

questions.explanation: The redesigned Form W-4 (effective 2020) eliminated withholding allowances. It now uses a system based on filing status, income from multiple jobs, dependents, and other adjustments (additional withholding or deductions). Employees only need to submit a new W-4 when circumstances change.
questions.tip: Post-2020 W-4 eliminated 'allowances' - now based on filing status, multiple jobs, dependents, and adjustments.

questions.question: The failure to file penalty is generally:

options.A: 0.5% of unpaid tax per month, up to 25%
options.B: 5% of unpaid tax per month, up to 25%
options.C: 10% of unpaid tax per month, up to 50%
options.D: A flat $500 penalty

questions.explanation: The failure to file penalty is 5% of unpaid tax for each month (or part of month) the return is late, up to a maximum of 25%. This is much steeper than the failure to pay penalty (0.5% per month). If both apply, the failure to file penalty is reduced by the failure to pay penalty.
questions.tip: File penalty (5%/month) is 10x worse than pay penalty (0.5%/month). Always file on time!

questions.question: The accuracy-related penalty for substantial understatement of income tax is:

options.A: 10% of the understatement
options.B: 20% of the understatement
options.C: 50% of the understatement
options.D: 75% of the understatement

questions.explanation: The accuracy-related penalty under Section 6662 is 20% of the underpayment attributable to negligence, substantial understatement of income tax, or substantial valuation misstatement. Substantial understatement occurs when the understatement exceeds the greater of 10% of the correct tax or $5,000.
questions.tip: Most accuracy penalties = 20%. The 75% rate is for fraud (Section 6663).

questions.question: The general statute of limitations for the IRS to assess additional tax is:

options.A: 2 years from the date of filing
options.B: 3 years from the later of filing or due date
options.C: 5 years from the date of filing
options.D: 7 years from the due date

questions.explanation: The general assessment period is 3 years from the later of the filing date or the due date (including extensions). If a return is filed early, the statute runs from the due date. Special rules extend the period to 6 years for substantial omissions and indefinitely for fraud or failure to file.
questions.tip: General rule = 3 years from later of filing or due date. Extended to 6 years for 25%+ omission.

questions.question: The statute of limitations for IRS assessment is extended to 6 years when:

options.A: The taxpayer files for an extension
options.B: The taxpayer omits more than 25% of gross income
options.C: The taxpayer claims the earned income credit
options.D: The return is filed electronically

questions.explanation: The assessment period extends to 6 years when the taxpayer omits gross income exceeding 25% of the gross income stated on the return. For example, if stated gross income is $100,000 and the omission is $30,000 (30%), the 6-year rule applies. Fraud creates an unlimited period.
questions.tip: 25%+ gross income omission = 6 years. Fraud = unlimited. Otherwise = 3 years.

questions.question: A taxpayer may file an amended return (Form 1040-X) to claim a refund within:

options.A: 2 years from the date tax was paid
options.B: 3 years from filing or 2 years from payment, whichever is later
options.C: 3 years from the original due date only
options.D: 4 years from the date the return was filed

questions.explanation: A refund claim must be filed within 3 years from the filing date of the original return (including extensions) OR 2 years from the date the tax was paid, whichever is later. If filed after 3 years, the refund is limited to amounts paid within the 2 years preceding the claim.
questions.tip: Refund claim deadline = later of 3 years from filing or 2 years from payment.

questions.question: A surviving spouse may use the qualifying surviving spouse filing status for how long after the year of the spouse's death?

options.A: One year only
options.B: Two years
options.C: Three years
options.D: Indefinitely if not remarried

questions.explanation: Qualifying surviving spouse status is available for the two tax years following the year of the spouse's death, provided the taxpayer doesn't remarry, maintains a household as the principal residence for a dependent child, and pays more than half the household costs. This status allows use of MFJ tax rates and standard deduction.
questions.tip: QSS = 2 years after death year. Must have dependent child and maintain household.

questions.question: U.S. citizens living abroad receive an automatic extension to file their return until:

options.A: April 15
options.B: June 15
options.C: August 15
options.D: October 15

questions.explanation: U.S. citizens and resident aliens living abroad receive an automatic 2-month extension to file (June 15) without filing Form 4868. However, interest on unpaid tax still runs from April 15. They can file Form 4868 by June 15 for an additional extension to October 15.
questions.tip: Citizens abroad = automatic extension to June 15 for filing (but interest still starts April 15).

questions.question: A taxpayer with uneven income throughout the year may reduce estimated tax penalties by using:

options.A: The prior year safe harbor method only
options.B: The current year safe harbor method only
options.C: The annualized income installment method
options.D: The quarterly averaging method

questions.explanation: The annualized income installment method allows taxpayers with uneven income (seasonal businesses, large year-end bonuses) to base each quarterly payment on income actually earned through that period. This prevents overpayment in early quarters when income is low and avoids penalties when income arrives later.
questions.tip: Uneven income? Use annualized installment method to match payments to when income is earned.

questions.question: Which of the following would most likely constitute reasonable cause for penalty abatement?

options.A: Ignorance of tax law
options.B: Reliance on incorrect advice from a tax professional
options.C: Disagreement with the tax law
options.D: Inability to pay due to voluntary financial decisions

questions.explanation: Reasonable reliance on incorrect advice from a qualified tax professional can constitute reasonable cause for penalty abatement, provided the taxpayer supplied accurate information to the professional. Ignorance of law, disagreement with law, and voluntary financial decisions generally do not constitute reasonable cause.
questions.tip: Reasonable cause = reliance on professional advice, death/serious illness, fire/disaster. Not ignorance of law.

questions.question: An Identity Protection PIN (IP PIN) is:

options.A: Required for all electronic filers
options.B: A 6-digit number used to prevent fraudulent returns
options.C: The same as a taxpayer's Social Security Number
options.D: Assigned only to victims of identity theft

questions.explanation: An IP PIN is a 6-digit number assigned to eligible taxpayers to help prevent the use of their SSN on fraudulent returns. While initially provided to identity theft victims, the IRS now allows any taxpayer to opt into the IP PIN program. It changes annually and must be included on the return.
questions.tip: IP PIN = voluntary 6-digit number that changes yearly. Anyone can now opt in for extra protection.

questions.question: Tax return documentation should generally be retained for at least:

options.A: 1 year after filing
options.B: 3 years after filing or due date, whichever is later
options.C: 7 years after filing
options.D: Indefinitely for all returns

questions.explanation: Records should be kept at least 3 years from filing or due date to match the general statute of limitations. Records supporting property basis should be kept until the property is disposed of plus the statute period. Records for worthless securities or bad debts should be kept 7 years.
questions.tip: General rule = 3 years. Keep property basis records until disposal + 3 years. Keep employment records 4 years.

questions.question: When a taxpayer dies, the final income tax return:

options.A: Is filed by the deceased taxpayer's estate
options.B: Covers only income through the date of death
options.C: Must be filed within 30 days of death
options.D: Includes the estate's income for the remainder of the year

questions.explanation: The final Form 1040 for a deceased taxpayer includes only income from January 1 through the date of death. The return is filed by the personal representative (executor/administrator) or surviving spouse. Income earned by the estate after death is reported on Form 1041 (estate income tax return).
questions.tip: Final 1040 = Jan 1 to death date only. Estate income after death goes on Form 1041.

questions.question: A business must file Form 1099-NEC to report payments to a non-employee service provider when payments total at least:

options.A: $100 during the year
options.B: $400 during the year
options.C: $600 during the year
options.D: $1,000 during the year

questions.explanation: Form 1099-NEC must be filed for nonemployee compensation of $600 or more paid during the year. This includes payments to independent contractors, freelancers, and other non-employees for services. The form must be provided to the recipient by January 31 and filed with the IRS.
questions.tip: 1099-NEC threshold = $600. Same threshold applies to 1099-MISC for rent, royalties, etc.

questions.question: A U.S. person must file an FBAR (FinCEN Form 114) if the aggregate value of foreign financial accounts exceeds what amount at any time during the year?
questions.explanation: An FBAR must be filed if the aggregate value of all foreign financial accounts exceeds $10,000 at any time during the calendar year. This is filed electronically with FinCEN (not the IRS) by April 15 with an automatic extension to October 15. Penalties for non-filing can be severe.
questions.tip: FBAR = $10,000 aggregate max value at ANY point in year. Filed with FinCEN, not IRS.

questions.question: Form 8938 (FATCA reporting) differs from the FBAR in that Form 8938:

options.A: Has a lower reporting threshold than FBAR
options.B: Is filed with FinCEN
options.C: Is attached to the income tax return
options.D: Only covers bank accounts

questions.explanation: Form 8938 is filed with the IRS as an attachment to Form 1040, while FBAR is filed separately with FinCEN. Form 8938 has higher thresholds ($50,000/$200,000 depending on residence and filing status) and covers a broader range of assets including certain foreign stocks and interests, not just bank accounts.
questions.tip: Form 8938 = filed with 1040, higher thresholds, broader assets. FBAR = separate FinCEN filing, $10K threshold.

questions.question: The civil fraud penalty under Section 6663 equals what percentage of the underpayment attributable to fraud?
questions.explanation: The civil fraud penalty is 75% of the underpayment attributable to fraud. This is significantly higher than the 20% accuracy-related penalty. The IRS must prove fraud by clear and convincing evidence. The fraud penalty preempts the accuracy-related penalty for the same underpayment.
questions.tip: Fraud = 75% penalty + unlimited assessment period. IRS must prove by clear and convincing evidence.

questions.question: The interest rate on individual tax underpayments is:

options.A: A flat 6% annually
options.B: The federal short-term rate plus 2 percentage points
options.C: The federal short-term rate plus 3 percentage points
options.D: The prime rate plus 1 percentage point

questions.explanation: For individual taxpayers, the underpayment interest rate is the federal short-term rate plus 3 percentage points (rounded to the nearest whole percent). The rate is adjusted quarterly. This is higher than the corporate underpayment rate (federal short-term rate plus 3%) for large corporate underpayments.
questions.tip: Individual underpayment interest = short-term federal rate + 3%. Adjusted quarterly.

questions.question: Under Section 6501(e), an overstatement of basis that results in an omission from gross income of more than 25% of gross income stated on the return:

options.A: Does not affect the statute of limitations
options.B: Extends the assessment period to 6 years
options.C: Creates an unlimited assessment period
options.D: Only applies to real property transactions

questions.explanation: The extended 6-year assessment period applies when there is an omission from gross income exceeding 25% of stated gross income. An overstatement of basis that leads to an understatement of gain (and thus omission of income) can trigger this extension. This was clarified by legislation following the Supreme Court's Home Concrete decision.
questions.tip: Basis overstatement creating 25%+ income omission = 6-year statute. Per IRC Section 6501(e)(1)(B).

questions.question: When the IRS prepares a substitute for return (SFR) for a non-filer:

options.A: The taxpayer cannot later file their own return
options.B: The statute of limitations begins running from the SFR date
options.C: The statute of limitations never begins to run
options.D: The taxpayer receives all deductions and credits they would normally claim

questions.explanation: When the IRS prepares a substitute for return, it is not considered a return filed by the taxpayer. Therefore, the statute of limitations for assessment never begins to run. The IRS can assess tax at any time. SFRs typically include only income reported to the IRS without favorable deductions or filing status.
questions.tip: SFR = not a valid return for SOL purposes. Taxpayer should always file their own return to start the clock.

questions.question: For an individual taxpayer, a substantial understatement of income tax exists when the understatement exceeds the greater of:

options.A: 5% of tax shown on return or $2,500
options.B: 10% of tax shown on return or $5,000
options.C: 15% of tax shown on return or $7,500
options.D: 20% of tax shown on return or $10,000

questions.explanation: A substantial understatement exists when the understatement exceeds the greater of 10% of the tax required to be shown on the return or $5,000. The penalty is 20% of the underpayment attributable to the substantial understatement. Adequate disclosure with reasonable basis can reduce the understatement amount.
questions.tip: Substantial understatement = greater of 10% of correct tax or $5,000. Results in 20% penalty.

questions.question: Traditional innocent spouse relief under Section 6015(b) requires all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: An understatement of tax attributable to erroneous items of the other spouse
options.B: The requesting spouse did not know and had no reason to know of the understatement
options.C: The requesting spouse is divorced or legally separated from the other spouse
options.D: It would be inequitable to hold the requesting spouse liable

questions.explanation: Traditional innocent spouse relief under 6015(b) does not require divorce or separation. Requirements are: (1) joint return filed, (2) understatement due to other spouse's erroneous items, (3) requesting spouse didn't know/have reason to know of understatement, and (4) inequitable to hold requesting spouse liable. Separation relief under 6015(c) requires living apart.
questions.tip: 6015(b) innocent spouse = no divorce required. 6015(c) separation relief = must be separated 12+ months.

questions.question: The estimated tax penalty does not apply if the total tax liability minus withholding is less than:
questions.explanation: No estimated tax penalty applies if the balance due (tax minus withholding and credits) is less than $1,000. This de minimis exception prevents penalties for small underpayments. The $1,000 threshold applies regardless of whether the taxpayer met the safe harbor requirements.
questions.tip: $1,000 rule: If you owe less than $1,000 at filing, no estimated tax penalty regardless of payments.

questions.question: A John Doe summons is used by the IRS to:

options.A: Summon a specific taxpayer by name
options.B: Obtain information about taxpayers whose identities are unknown
options.C: Collect taxes from a defaulting taxpayer
options.D: Issue a levy against a taxpayer's assets

questions.explanation: A John Doe summons is used when the IRS seeks information about taxpayers whose identities are not known. It requires court approval and must show reasonable basis for believing the group has failed to comply with tax law. This tool is often used to obtain records from third parties about potentially non-compliant taxpayers.
questions.tip: John Doe summons = fishing for unknown taxpayers. Requires court approval. Used against banks, crypto exchanges, etc.

questions.question: When both failure to file and failure to pay penalties apply for the same month:

options.A: Both penalties apply in full
options.B: Only the failure to file penalty applies
options.C: Only the failure to pay penalty applies
options.D: The failure to file penalty is reduced by the failure to pay penalty

questions.explanation: When both penalties apply for the same month, the failure to file penalty (5%) is reduced by the failure to pay penalty (0.5%), resulting in a net 4.5% failure to file penalty plus 0.5% failure to pay penalty = 5% total for that month. This prevents double-counting the failure to pay component.
questions.tip: Penalty stacking: 5% FTF is reduced by 0.5% FTP = 4.5% + 0.5% = 5% total per month (not 5.5%).

questions.question: The IRS generally has how long to collect an assessed tax?

options.A: 3 years from assessment
options.B: 6 years from assessment
options.C: 10 years from assessment
options.D: Unlimited time

questions.explanation: The IRS has 10 years from the date of assessment to collect taxes. This is the collection statute expiration date (CSED). The period can be extended by agreement, bankruptcy, or other specified events. After the CSED, the IRS can no longer legally collect the debt.
questions.tip: 3 years to assess, 10 years to collect (CSED). Watch for events that toll the collection period.

questions.question: Failure to disclose a listed transaction on Form 8886 can result in a penalty of:

options.C: 75% of the tax benefit
options.D: The greater of $200,000 or 75% of the decrease in tax

questions.explanation: The penalty for failing to disclose a listed transaction is $200,000 for individuals ($100,000 for others) or, if greater, 75% of the decrease in tax shown on the return as a result of the transaction. Listed transactions are abusive tax avoidance transactions specifically identified by the IRS.
questions.tip: Listed transaction disclosure penalty = greater of $200K or 75% of tax benefit. Very severe penalty.

questions.question: In a community property state, when spouses file separately:

options.A: Each spouse reports only their own earned income
options.B: Each spouse reports half of the combined community income
options.C: Community property rules do not apply for federal tax purposes
options.D: Only the higher-earning spouse reports community income

questions.explanation: In community property states, when spouses file separately, each spouse must report half of the total community income and deductions. This includes half of the other spouse's earnings. Separate property income is reported by the spouse who owns it. Community property states include Arizona, California, Idaho, Louisiana, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin.
questions.tip: Community property MFS = each reports 50% of combined community income. Can't shift income by filing separately.
